title.children: Mohammed says he's been offered $100m for his home. This is why he'll never leave

image.altText: A man inspects as Palestinians search for casualties at the site of an Israeli strike on a house.

items.synopsis: A board game contest between human and machine in 2016 marked the birth of modern AI. This is the moment the world changed forever.

image.altText: A plate with an ornate menu sits on a table with floral decorations and gold cutlery

items.synopsis: Anthony Albanese and his partner will be treated to an exquisite meal when they sit down as guests of honour at a White House state dinner tomorrow, but the event has been significantly toned down in light of the Israel-Gaza war.

title.children: Star-studded guest list and a five-star menu: Here's what we know about Albanese's state dinner

image.altText: Woman with hazel eye and dark hair with sungalsses on head smiles at camera

items.synopsis: A land and air search is continuing in Kakadu National Park to find 35-year-old Jessica Louise Stephens, who police say travelled to the park on October 19.

image.altText: A young white boy with intellectual disability. He is in a classroom and being spoken to by a teacher's aide

items.synopsis: Debate has erupted again over the future of special schools following the disability royal commission's final report. Here's why the issue is so complex and personal.

image.altText: man in front of a brick wall looking into the camera

items.synopsis: Paedophile teacher Grahame Harold Steele died a decade ago and was never criminally prosecuted. An inquiry has allowed one of his victims, Grant Holland, to finally feel heard for the first time.

title.children: A 'hopeless' police sting couldn't bring down Grant's abuser. 48 years later, he's finding validation

image.altText: Cars stalled in morning peak hour traffic in Annerley, Brisbane

items.synopsis: The ASX falls after the release of the September quarter inflation data, with fuel, electricity and rents behind the higher-than-expected jump, as investors weigh the possibility of a November rate hike by the RBA. Follow live.

title.children: Rising fuel prices behind higher-than-expected jump in inflation, ASX falls as markets consider possible rate hike

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Rising petrol prices were a key factor in the September inflation figure being higher than economists had expected — but that was based on fuel prices before the Israel-Gaza war started earlier this month. Oil prices have been rising as a result of the war, but AMP deputy chief economist Diana Mousina says they haven't increased too significantly just yet, so there is a possibility petrol prices could remain at their current (but still elevated) levels. Ms Mousina still expects some prices will continue to come down in the coming months, and says "we will be surprised at how far inflation can fall" next year as Australia braces for softer economic growth. You can watch her full chat with finance presenter Alicia Barry about inflation, oil prices and how the RBA might make sense of it all below:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 📺 Will inflation continue to come down, or does the Israel-Gaza war make it uncertain?

children.content: Rising petrol prices were a key factor in the September inflation figure being higher than economists had expected — but that was based on fuel prices before the Israel-Gaza war started earlier this month.
Oil prices have been rising as a result of the war, but
AMP deputy chief economist Diana Mousina
says they haven't increased too significantly just yet, so there is a possibility petrol prices could remain at their current (but still elevated) levels.
Ms Mousina still expects some prices will continue to come down in the coming months, and says
"we will be surprised at how far inflation can fall" next year
as Australia braces for softer economic growth.
You can watch her full chat with
finance presenter Alicia Barry
about inflation, oil prices and how the RBA might make sense of it all below:

document.title: Inflation lifts 1.2 per cent in September quarter

titleAlt.lg: Inflation lifts 1.2 per cent in September quarter
titleAlt.md: Inflation lifts 1.2 per cent in September quarter
titleAlt.sm: Inflation lifts 1.2 per cent in September quarter

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Treasurer Jim Chalmers says today's inflation data reflects the global economic experience — that although it is moderating, it is proving to be more persistent. Speaking in Canberra about the figures, Mr Chalmers said the 1.2% September increase was consistent with Treasury forecasts, but warned further volatility in inflation is likely in coming months in response to oil markets and fuel prices. "Production cuts and disruptions in global oil markets are a key driver of inflation in the global economy and here at home, with Australians facing higher fuel prices at the bowser," he said. "Petrol prices increased 7.2% in the [September] quarter, contributing a quarter of a percentage point to quarterly inflation. "We shouldn't be surprised to see some volatility in inflation figures going forward, particularly given the global uncertainty from the conflict in the Middle East and the war in Ukraine. "We understand that inflation and higher interest rates that are already in the system are biting households hard and we're acting to make things a little easier."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Treasurer: 'We shouldn't be surprised to see some volatility in inflation figures going forward'

children.content: Treasurer Jim Chalmers
says today's inflation data reflects the global economic experience — that although it is moderating, it is proving to be more persistent.
Speaking in Canberra about the figures, Mr Chalmers said the 1.2% September increase was
consistent with Treasury forecasts
, but warned further volatility in inflation is likely in coming months in response to oil markets and fuel prices.
"Production cuts and
disruptions in global oil markets are a key driver of inflation
in the global economy and here at home, with Australians facing higher fuel prices at the bowser," he said.
"Petrol prices increased 7.2% in the [September] quarter, contributing a quarter of a percentage point to quarterly inflation.
"We
shouldn't be surprised to see some volatility in inflation figures
going forward, particularly given the
global uncertainty from the conflict in the Middle East
and the
war in Ukraine
"We understand that inflation and higher interest rates that are already in the system are biting households hard and we're acting to make things a little easier."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: If you're after another hot take on inflation, you're in the right place. My colleague, senior business correspondent Peter Ryan told The World Today that there's no two ways about it — these inflation numbers will be a big concern for the RBA board. "That's because while the pace of inflation seems to be slowing, it's not slowing fast enough — it's still higher than expected at 5.4% over the year and lower than 6% in the last quarter — but still well above the 2 to 3% target where the RBA eventually wants it," he said. If you've got a spare four minutes, you can listen to his full analysis below:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 🎧 Why the RBA is more concerned with the pace of inflation than the current rate
